message.content: This question requires basic knowledge about the purpose and regulations of national parks. National parks have rules in place to protect the vulnerable animal inhabitants within the parks. These rules aim to preserve and maintain the habitats and ecosystems, ensuring the safety and well-being of the animals. Option (A) is incorrect because the rules in national parks often aim to protect and preserve fragile animal species rather than curtail their growth. Option (B) is incorrect because national parks are generally protected from mining and exploitation of natural resources. Option (C) is incorrect because littering is typically prohibited in national parks as it can harm the environment and wildlife.

This question requires knowledge about the purposes and regulations of national parks. National parks have rules in place to protect the environment and wildlife within them. These rules often include prohibitions on activities that could harm or disturb vulnerable animal inhabitants. Option (A) is incorrect because national parks aim to preserve and protect fragile animal species, not curtail their growth. Option (B) is incorrect because national parks are generally established to conserve natural resources, not exploit them through mining. Option (C) is incorrect because national parks actively discourage littering and have protocols in place for waste management.

This question requires basic understanding of the purpose and regulations of national parks. National parks have rules in place to protect the natural environment and preserve the habitats of vulnerable animal species. These rules aim to protect the animal inhabitants in the parks, not curtail their growth as mentioned in option (A). Option (B) is incorrect because mining of natural resources is generally prohibited in national parks. Option (C) is also incorrect because littering is not allowed in national parks.

This question requires some general knowledge about national parks and their purpose. National parks have rules in place to protect and preserve the natural environment and wildlife within the park. Option (A) is incorrect because the rules in national parks aim to protect vulnerable animal species, not curtail their growth. Option (B) is also incorrect because national parks are not open to mining of natural resources as it would harm the environment. Option (C) is incorrect because national parks do not allow for littering, as it would be detrimental to the park's ecosystem. Option (D) is correct because the rules in national parks are designed to protect vulnerable animal inhabitants and ensure their survival.

Option (A) is incorrect because the rules of national parks are not aimed at curtailment of growth but rather to protect fragile animal species. Option (B) is incorrect because national parks are typically established to conserve natural resources and prevent mining activities. Option (C) is incorrect because littering is typically prohibited in national parks to maintain their cleanliness and integrity.
